s.text: In the post-Soviet chaos, youngsters found more ways to duck conscription, and the quality of the average soldier plummeted.
Russia has reason to invade Chechnya: The rebellious province has been agitating to form a separate, antagonistic Muslim state.
The best and brightest joined the officer corps.
Russia makes no serious effort to train them, because it doesn't have qualified noncommissioned officers, and its officers can't control the conscripts.
The best and brightest joined the officer corps.
The breakup of the U.S.S.R. shattered the army into 15 pieces, as Russia lost nukes, ships, bases, and many of its best officers to newly independent republics.
The state pampered officers with special stores, chauffeured cars, and dachas .
Russia makes no serious effort to train them, because it doesn't have qualified noncommissioned officers, and its officers can't control the conscripts.
Russia makes no serious effort to train them, because it doesn't have qualified noncommissioned officers, and its officers can't control the conscripts.
The best and brightest joined the officer corps.
The breakup of the U.S.S.R. shattered the army into 15 pieces, as Russia lost nukes, ships, bases, and many of its best officers to newly independent republics.
The state pampered officers with special stores, chauffeured cars, and dachas .
Russia makes no serious effort to train them, because it doesn't have qualified noncommissioned officers, and its officers can't control the conscripts.
Hazing is unbelievably brutal: More than 1,000 soldiers are murdered every year by their brothers-in-arms, and more than 500 kill themselves because of the horrific conditions.
This "pacification" has killed many Chechen guerrillas and civilians and has turned most of the survivors into refugees.

U.S. officials certainly exaggerated the competence of the Soviet military during the Cold War, but it was still a great force: 6 million men under arms, a 3-to-1 tank advantage, a 2-to-1 aircraft advantage.
(The only good news about the military is that it has regained secure control over its active nuclear weapons--though not over discarded nuclear material.)
Western analysts now fear that the generals are using Chechnya to reassert control over national security and foreign policy.
